"This has been the heart of the problem in Detroit," said Sergio Marchionne , who also heads up Fiat, the Italian auto company. Alan Mulally said Ford has learned that it has to deal with the current reality. You have to match production to real demand and accelerate development of new products that people will want to buy. For Ford that meant going with a plan for extensive restructuring to a consortium of banks and borrowing$ 23.5 billion, he said. For GM and Chrysler it meant bankruptcy filings and huge bailouts
